Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalyst and its application in dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene Zhengpai Zhang Investigation Writing – original draft Tieqiang Zeng Methodology Validation Data curation Chunling Wei Conceptualization Supervision Lei Song Supervision Resources Changxi Miao Writing – review & editing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, SINOPEC Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Shanghai 201208, China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis SINOPEC Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology Shanghai 201208 China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, SINOPEC, Shanghai 201208, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The continuous pursuit of green, low-carbon, and efficient processes in catalysis necessitates a deep understanding of catalytic reaction mechanisms and the structure-performance relationship of catalysts. Styrene, a vital monomer in the chemical industry, is primarily produced through the catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene over Fe-based catalysts. This study prepared a series of Fe-K-Mg catalysts promoted with different CeO2 contents. Various techniques such as mercury intrusion, particle strength tests, scanning electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and temperature-programmed techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts' physical properties, surface, and bulk structures. The results indicate that the bulk density and crush strength of the catalyst are closely related to the pore structure and grain size of potassium β-ferrite. The surface of the Ce-promoted catalyst contains potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17, cerium dioxide, and potassium carbonate, while the bulk structure consists of potassium β-ferrite and cerium dioxide. The addition of Ce enhances the catalytic activity of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, but the selectivity of styrene shows the opposite trend. The Fe-K-Mg catalyst containing 12% CeO2 exhibited the highest single-pass yield of styrene, reaching 70.9%. This study also discusses the possible effect of CeO2 on the performance of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dehydrogenation Ethylbenzene Styrene β-ferrite Ce doping Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Styrene is a critical monomer, mainly used to manufacture plastics, latex, synthetic rubber, insulating materials, which find widespread application in various industries such as automobiles, home appliances, pharmaceuticals, dyes, and pesticides. The primary route for styrene production route is the catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene, accounting for about 85% of the global styrene production capacity [1]. However, the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction is highly endothermic and energy-intensive, motivating researchers worldwide to explore and develop green, low-carbon dehydrogenation catalysts and efficient process technologies. Since the 1980s, SINOPEC has successfully developed GS series styrene catalysts, which have gained popularity in both domestic and international markets [1–3]. β-ferrite (MFe11O17) has significant applications in catalysis, biomedicine, magnetic resonance imaging, data storage, and potential applications as sensors and electrodes [4,4]. KFe11O17 is a K+-β-ferrite with an ideal composition, which exists in alkyl aromatic dehydrogenation catalysts as the precursor of the active phase [5,6]. In the Fe-K system, introducing a small amount of Mg has been proven to promote the formation of KFe11O17, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity [7,8]. Due to its high defect density, lattice oxygen mobility, and reversible oxygen storage capacity (OSC), CeO2 is widely used in various systems such as photo-, electro-, thermal-, and environmental catalysis [9]. Among ethylbenzene dehydrogenation catalysts, many studies and patents employ cerium oxides as promoters. Hirano [10] prepared catalysts using iron oxide, potassium carbonate, and cerium carbonate as raw materials and found that Ce enhances the surface basicity and H-extraction capacity of the surface. They also disclosed that adding Ce to the Fe-K system reduces the activation energy of styrene formation from 30 kcal/mol to 25.6 kcal/mol and increases the formation rate of styrene and toluene through kinetic studies [11]. Using cerium nitrate as a raw material, Abe et al. [12] studied the effect of Ce on the Fe-K system and found that Ce inhibits the grain growth of mixed oxides and increases the yield of styrene by increasing the specific surface area. Aleksandr et al. [13] suggested that Ce4+ has sufficient ionic strength to strengthen the polarization of Fe-O bonds and improve the surface alkalinity of the catalyst. Ce also promotes the electron exchange between Fe2+ and Fe3+ and inhibits the complete reduction of potassium polyferrite to Fe3O4. By studying the effect of Ce on the composition of the Fe phase, they found that using cerium carbonate as a raw material, the increase in Ce content inhibits the formation of potassium polyferrite and promotes the formation of small grain size α-Fe2O3. α-Fe2O3 and potassium carbonate under the reaction conditions promote more KFeO2 formation, thus contributing to increased activity. Anikanova and Dvoretskii [14] observed that adding Ce to the alkali metal-polyferrite system will cause the Fe2+ content to rise and destabilizes of the polyferrite, especially at high Ce contents. Trębala et al. [15] found that Ce can modify the surface electronic properties of β-K2Fe22O34 and inhibit K+ desorption to a certain extent. In summary, the promotion effect of Ce on the catalytic performance is multifarious and is influenced by the catalyst components, raw materials, and preparation methods. Among the catalyst systems for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, much of the research focuses on the Fe, Fe-K or Ce, Mo, Mg, and Ca-promoted Fe-K systems. However, studies on the four-component Fe-K-Mg-Ce catalyst in details have yet to be reported. In this study, we examine the effects of varying CeO2 contents on the morphology, structure, and reduction properties of Fe-K-Mg catalysts using various analytical techniques, including mercury porosimeter, particle strength tester, scanning electron microscope, Raman spectrometer, X-ray diffraction, Mössbauer spectrometer, and temperature-programmed techniques. Additionally, we evaluate the dehydrogenation performance of Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg composite catalysts and discuss the role of Ce in this system. Our findings provide a valuable reference for investigating the structure-performance relationship of catalysts in complex systems and the development of industrial catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Iron oxide (AR, ≥99.0%, Sinopharm), potassium carbonate (anhydrous, ≥99.0%, Sinopharm), magnesium oxide (AR, 98%, Aladdin) were weighed according to the ratio of Fe2O3:K2O:MgO=86.5:12:1.5 (wt%), mixed well with an appropriate amount of deionized water. Then, the agglomerate was extruded, cut into cylindrical particles with a diameter of 3 mm and a length of 5–6 mm, and calcined at 900 °C in a muffle furnace to obtain a Fe-K-Mg catalyst, denoted as Ce-0. With a constant weight ratio of Fe2O3:K2O:MgO, iron oxide, potassium carbonate, magnesium oxide, cerium nitrate (hexahydrate, 99.5% metals basis, Aladdin) were weighed and mixed evenly with an appropriate amount of deionized water according to the CeO2 mass fraction of 2.5%, 5%, 12%, and 20%. Likewise, the agglomerates were extruded and pelletized into cylindrical particles with a diameter of 3 mm and a length of 5–6 mm and were calcined at 900 °C to obtain Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalysts, respectively recorded as Ce-2.5, Ce-5, Ce-12, and Ce-20. 2.2 Characterization Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded in a Tristar 3000 Micromeritics system at 77 K. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore structure analysis was carried out by Thermo Fisher Pascal 140/240 mercury intrusion porosimeter, with a low-pressure range of 0.1–400 kPa and a high-pressure range of 0.1–200 MPa. The crush strength is measured by the DL-II smart particle strength meter. For each sample, 20 samples with a length of 5 mm are selected, and the arithmetic mean value is taken as the crush resistance with the unit N/5 mm. The surface morphology was taken by Zeiss Merlin Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) from ZEISS Company, Germany. The elemental composition was acquired by the energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) with point analysis and mapping mode. Microscopic Raman spectrum was measured using LabRAM Aramis from Horiba Jobin Yvon Company with the laser wavelength 532 nm. X-ray diffraction (XRD) adopts a D8 Advances SS X-ray powder diffractometer from Bruker, Germany, using a Cu-Kα radiation source (λ=1.5406 Å), with a scanning range of 5–70° and a scanning rate of 5°/min. After measuring the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the crystal plane corresponding to the most intense diffraction peak of the phase, the grain size is estimated by the Scherrer formula: D = 0.89 λ Δ cos θ where, D is the grain size, λ is the X-ray wavelength, Δ and θ are the full widths at half maximum of the diffraction peak and the diffraction angle, respectively. XRD analysis was conducted on powder samples of the fresh catalysts and block-shaped particles of the spent catalysts after the reaction. 57Fe Mössbauer spectra were recorded at room temperature using a constant acceleration spectrometer with a 9.2 × 108Bq 57Co (Pd) source in transmission geometry from WissEl GmbH, Germany. Spectral parameters were estimated by the least-squares fitting, the relative content was determined by integrating the absorption peak area of each phase, and the isomer shift was calibrated with an α-Fe foil of 25 μm thickness. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on an AutoChem II 2920 temperature-programmed chemisorption instrument from Micromeritics Instruments, USA, with a 10% H2/Ar atmosphere and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The PX200 series multipurpose adsorption instrument of Tianjin Pengxiang Company was used for NH3-programmed temperature desorption. The 10% NH3/He atmosphere was adsorbed at room temperature. After purging, the temperature was raised to 650 °C in He at 10 °C/min to desorb NH3. The K content of the catalyst particles was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Varian 725-ES, Varian Analytical Ltd., US). 2.3 Catalytic performance test An isothermal stainless-steel reactor with an inner diameter of 2.5 cm was used to evaluate the catalytic performance of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. An amount of 100 mL of catalyst was placed in the reactor. The catalysts were tested under the following conditions: temperature 620 °C, atmospheric pressure, liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of ethylbenzene (GC, >99.5%, Aladdin) 1.0 h−1, and steam to ethylbenzene ratio by weight 2:1. The reactive products were analyzed by Agilent 5890 gas chromatography and detected by hydrogen flame-ionization detector (FID). The ethylbenzene conversion (XEB), product selectivity (Si) and styrene yield (YSM) are calculated based on the equations as follows: X E B = ( 1 − F o u t × C E B , o u t F i n × C E B , i n ) × 100 % S i = C i , o u t C S M , o u t + C B , o u t + C T , o u t × 100 % ( i = S M , B , o r T ) Y S M = X E B × S S M where, Fin and Fout denote the inlet and outlet flows rates, respectively, and CEB, CSM, CB, and CT denote the concentrations of ethylbenzene, styrene, benzene, and toluene, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical properties The physical properties of Fe-K-Mg catalysts with varying CeO2 contents are shown in Table 1 and Fig. 1 . The isotherms of the prepared catalysts exhibit a clear combination of type III and IV based on the IUPAC classification (Fig. 1a). Generally, the isotherms protrude toward the relative pressure P/P0 axis (type III), and the small adsorption amount of each sample derives from the weak interaction between the adsorbate N2 and the catalyst surface. The absence of Point B at low relative pressure P/P0 suggests a lack of micropore-rich structure in the catalyst samples. Capillary condensation occurs in the high P/P0 section, and H3-type adsorption hysteresis loops are observed (type IV). The hysteresis rings exhibit significant adsorption at the end of high relative pressure, which may arise from the slit-like pores formed by the assemblies of platelike particles. As the relative pressure approaches 1, the isotherm rises sharply, indicating a distinct macropore adsorption feature. Due to the limited analysis range of pore size from N2 adsorption-desorption, the pore size distribution was obtained by a mercury porosimeter. The median pore diameter is the corresponding pore diameter at 50% of the maximum pore volume during the mercury injection process (Table 1). The median pore diameter and total pore volume of the catalyst particles decrease from 254.6 nm and 249.0 mm3/g without Ce to 215.0 nm and 141.3 mm3/g, respectively, as the Ce content increases to 5%. On the other hand, the median pore diameter and total pore volume increase to 357.5 nm and 367.2 mm3/g when the CeO2 content rises to 20%. Similarly, the specific surface area of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst decreases to 2.62 m2/g for Ce-5 and then rises to 4.53 m2/g for Ce-20. Contrarily, the tapped density of the catalyst particles increases from 1.05 kg/L without Ce to 1.35 kg/L with 5% Ce and subsequently decreases to 0.87 kg/L for Ce-20 (Table 1, Fig. 1b). The relationship of the crush strength and the bulk density with CeO2 content is consistent, with both first increasing and then decreasing as the Ce content increases, and the maximum crush strength is 166.9 N/5 mm for the Ce-5 sample. In this catalyst system, the tapped density and crush strength negatively correlate with pore diameter and volume as the Ce content increases. 3.2 Morphology and surface properties The surface morphology and elemental distribution of the Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalyst are depicted in Figs. 2 and S1, respectively. In Ce-free Fe-K-Mg catalyst, the catalyst's surface presents anomalous sheet-like features. As shown in Fig. S1a, Fe, K, and Mg elements are uniformly dispersed in both dark and bright regions. Upon introduction of Ce into the Fe-K-Mg catalyst, hexagonal prism-shaped flaky crystals appear on the surface, indicating that Ce promotes the formation and growth of potassium polyferrite crystals [7]. Combined with the point-scan spectra in Fig. S1b, Ce is scarcely present in the hexagonal grains of potassium polyferrite, but is enriched in the nanocrystals on the surface of polyferrite crystals [16]. With the increase of Ce content, the tiny particles on the surface of Ce-12 and Ce-20 samples become more prominent. Further addition of Ce up to 20% retains the hexagonal lamella structure, but significantly reduces the particle size of the potassium polyferrite on the surface. From the perspective of pore structure, all catalysts possess discernible macroporous features. The pore structure of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst without Ce is large and uneven. Upon addition of Ce at 2.5–5%, the macropores in the catalyst become smaller and uniform. Further addition of Ce up to 20% results in a larger pore structure. The regularity of the pore size coincides with the findings of mercury intrusion. The Raman spectrum of the fresh Fe-K-Mg catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 , and it shows that the Raman scattering peaks are mainly ascribed to potassium polyferrite. Specifically, the peak at 168 cm−1 corresponds to the E1g vibration peak of the S-block from the spinel structure of potassium polyferrite, while the peaks at 365 and 400 cm−1 correspond to the A1g symmetrical vibration of the FeO6 octahedra [17]. The shoulder peaks of 419 and 712 cm−1 are assigned to the bending and stretching vibration (A1g) of the FeO4 tetrahedra, respectively. Moreover, the peak at 508 cm−1 corresponds to (FeO4)5− vibration [18], while the peaks at 618 cm−1 and 680 cm−1 correspond to the A1g vibration of the FeO6-octahedra (R-block) and the A1g vibration of the FeO5-bipyramid (R-block), respectively [19]. With the increase of CeO2 content, the peak at 462 cm−1 corresponding to the F2g symmetric stretching vibration of the Ce-O8 unit in the fluorite structure CeO2 on the catalyst surface [20] continues to increase. Overall, the CeO2 characteristic peaks of all samples are relatively weak, indicating that the crystallinity of CeO2 is poor, and CeO2 on the catalyst surface disperses well. In addition, all samples’ spectra show a weak peak at 1063 cm−1 corresponding to the ν1 (A1’) symmetrical stretching vibration of CO3 2−, which may be attributed to K2CO3 [21]. Therefore, the spectra reveal that the catalyst surface mainly contains potassium polyferrite, potassium carbonate, and cerium dioxide species. Of course, Ce-0 does not contain CeO2, and Ce-O vibration is not apparent due to the low Ce content in Ce-2.5. Generally, the surface structures of Fe-K-Mg catalysts promoted by different CeO2 content are relatively similar. 3.3 Bulk phase structure Fig. 4 presents the XRD patterns of the Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalysts. The Ce-0 sample exhibits diffraction peaks at 2θ=7.41°, 14.85°, 18.80°, 30.12°, 31.49°, 33.73°, 35.12°, 36.75°, 37.82°, 39.84°, 41.85°, 54.35°, 55.42°, 62.61°, corresponding to (002), (004), (102), (110), (107), (114), (201), (203), (116), (205), (206), (217), (2011), (220) crystal planes of hexagonal KFe11O17 (PDF#97-008-3285, ICDD 2009). After introducing Ce, new diffraction peaks emerge at 2θ=28.53°, 33.06°, 47.46°, and 56.31° corresponding to (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of CaF2 fluorite structure of CeO2, respectively (PDF#97-018-0955). The intensity of diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 increases with Ce content. Notably, the introduction of Ce does not shift the diffraction angle of potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17, indicating that Ce does not enter the crystal phase of potassium β-ferrite under the preparation conditions of this system. The diffraction peaks of MgO at 2θ=36.94°, 42.92°, and 62.30° correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of the cubic crystal system, respectively (PDF #00-045-0946). The patterns show that the addition of a small amount of MgO does not result in a diffraction peak. Since Mg2+ and Fe3+ are prone to form solid solutions, and MgO naturally exists in most iron ores, it is speculated that a small amount of Mg may dissolve in the crystal phase of potassium β-ferrite. It is worth noting that the crystalline phase of all samples does not contain α-Fe2O3 (PDF#97-009-6072), or another typical K2Fe10O16 phase (PDF#00-040-0135) of Fe-K oxides after high-temperature calcination, which may be due to the promotion effect of Mg on the formation of KFe11O17. From Table 2 , when the CeO2 content ranges from 2.5% to 12%, the grain size of CeO2 in the catalyst is about 20 nm. The Ce-20 sample exhibits a slightly smaller grain size of 17.8 nm. During the preparation process, cerium nitrate quickly dissolves in water after adding deionized water. Since the solubility of cerium nitrate is 1754 g/L at room temperature, the Ce source dissolved in water tends to become supersaturated in Ce-20 with a certain amount of deionized water. As the degree of supersaturation increases, the number of crystal nuclei increases, which leads to a decrease in particle size after crystallization and calcination. The characteristics of small grain size CeO2 are consistent with the characterization results of SEM and Raman, indicating that the introduction of Ce mainly increases the number of CeO2 grains, while the average grain size remains relatively unchanged. This finding is consistent with the results reported by Hirano [11]. Regarding the grain size of potassium β-ferrite in the catalyst, it increases from 65.0 nm to 80.4 nm when Ce addition increases from 0 to 5% and then decreases to 54.3 nm as the CeO2 content increases to 20%. Interestingly, the variation of the grain size of potassium β-ferrite with the increase of Ce content is consistent with the bulk density and crush strength, suggesting that the bulk density and crush strength are related to the crystallinity of the catalyst. From the Mössbauer spectra of the catalysts in Fig. 5 , the five samples exhibited similar absorption spectra. As the Ce content increases, the absorption peak intensity decreases gradually. The fitting results reveal that all samples can be fitted with four sextets, corresponding to the four magnetic splitting Fe3+ of Mg-doped KFe11O17 [22]. Previous studies have demonstrated that the structure of hexagonal KFe11O17 is equivalent to β-Al2O3, containing four crystallographically distinct Fe sites, two octahedral and two tetrahedral sites [23]. The symmetrical absorption doublet of Is=0.31 mm/s (Table 3 ), which can be attributed to the high-spin state Fe3+ [24], first appears in the Ce-12 sample, indicating the emergence of superparamagnetic iron oxide particles with a size of <15–20 nm [25]. The Ce-20 sample exhibited superparamagnetic phase, which accounted for 8.4% of the total area, with a significant increase in the content of nano-sized iron oxide. Compared with Ce-0, the hyperfine magnetic field (H) of potassium polyferrite Fe3+ in the Ce-containing sample decreased, possibly due to the presence of Ce4+ around Fe3+, which is consistent with the study by Hu et al. [26]. In addition, the sextet's isomer shift (Is) is significantly increased in the Fe-K-Mg catalyst with the introduction of Ce compared to the Ce-free sample (Table 3). The Is value tended to stabilize after the Ce content reached 5%. The isomer shift of the doublet in Ce-20 is slightly increased compared to Ce-12. This phenomenon suggests that as the Ce content increases, the s-electron density at the Fe nucleus in the catalyst decreases, and the valence state of Fe tends to decrease [27,28]. Generally, the room-temperature Mössbauer spectrum of α-Fe2O3 can be fitted into a sextet with a characteristic magnetic splitting H of 515kOe [23,29]. KFeO2, which has the same cristobalite structure as NaAlSiO4 with tetrahedral Fe atoms, shows a sextet with the magnetic splitting of 495kOe, isomer shift of 0.15 mm/s, and quaternary splitting of 0.03 mm/s [30]. Based on the fitting parameters, one can easily recognize that all samples do not contain α-Fe2O3 and KFeO2, which is consistent with the XRD patterns, indicating that adding a small amount of Mg and Ce promotes the formation of potassium polyferrite. 3.4 Reducibility The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of Fe-K-Mg catalysts with different Ce contents in an H2 atmosphere are shown in Fig. 6 . The TPR profiles show that the initial reduction temperature for all samples is around 350 °C and features a prominent, broad peak with at least three overlapping peaks in the range of 450–650 °C. Since K2CO3 reacts with H2 at atmospheric pressure 400 K–1200 K, the thermodynamic feasibility of ΔG>225 kJ/mol is unfavorable [31], and MgO will not be reduced below 1700 °C under a reducing atmosphere [32]. Hence, the H2 consumption primarily originates from Fe and Ce. Generally, the reduction of Fe2O3 under an H2 atmosphere goes through the following sequence: Fe2O3→Fe3O4→FeO (metastable state)→Fe [7]. Adding K inhibits the reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4, weakens the adsorption of H2, and increase the initial reduction temperature of iron oxides [33]. However, introducing a small amount of Mg promotes the reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4 [34] and the formation of the potassium polyferrite after the calcination of Fe-K oxides [7]. Chen et al. discovered that after introducing a small amount of Mg into the Fe-K catalyst, the reduction temperature of Fe2O3→Fe3O4 decreased, while the reduction peak of Fe2O3→Fe3O4 nearly vanished [7]. The position and intensity of the reduction peaks are identical for Ce-0 and Ce-2.5 samples, consistent with the spectrum of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst studied by Chen. There is noticeable H2 consumption at 562 and 624 °C, while a weak shoulder peak is exhibited at 512 °C. BH Shanks et al. analyzed the reducibility of potassium polyferrite [35,36] and found that K2Fe10O16 and K2Fe22O34 are rapidly reduced to form KFeO2 and Fe3O4 in an H2 atmosphere at a high temperature of 630 °C, and further reduction would form KFeO2, Fe3O4 and Fe. KFeO2 is relatively stable in the H2 atmosphere and starts to be reduced above 700 °C. Combined with the XRD above and other results, it is speculated that the reduction peaks at 562 and 624 °C correspond to the reduction of potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17→FeO and FeO→Fe, respectively, while the shoulder peak at 512 °C may be attributed to the reduction of potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17→Fe3O4. The reduction of pure CeO2 has been widely studied and is known to occur in two stages: the reduction of the surface shell at low temperatures and bulk CeO2 at high temperatures [37]. K makes CeO2 generate more oxygen vacancies, facilitating the reduction of low-temperature CeO2 [38]. However, Ce may form Fe-O-Ce solid solution with Fe oxide, and lattice hybridization makes more oxygen vacancies, leading to more reduction peaks of surface oxygen at low temperatures [39]. Therefore, distinguishing and identifying the reduction peaks in the low-temperature range of 400–650 °C, where the reduction of Ce4+ on the surface and KFe11O17→Fe3O4→FeO occurs almost simultaneously, can be extremely complicated [37]. The reduction peak temperature of the Ce-5 sample is almost the same as those of Ce-0 and Ce-2.5, while the reduction temperatures of the first two reduction peaks in the Ce-12 sample are reduced to 501 and 550 °C, respectively, and the three reduction peaks of the Ce-20 sample all significantly shift towards low temperature. This manifests that further increasing the CeO2 content beyond 12% promotes the reduction of potassium β-ferrite. Additionally, the peak height of the reduction at 624 °C attributed to FeO→Fe is the highest in Ce-0 and Ce-2.5 samples due to the K effect, while this peak height decreases significantly with CeO2 higher than 5%, indicating that Ce inhibits the complete reduction of FeO→Fe. In this system, the results of SEM, XRD, and Mössbauer all demonstrate that after the Ce content reaches 12%, the grain size of the catalyst decreases, and the content of nano-sized iron oxide gradually increases, likely increasing the catalyst's reducibility. Furthermore, H2 consumption between 700 and 800 °C can be ascribed to the reduction of KFeO2 and bulk CeO2. 3.5 Performance test and K loss The catalytic performance over the Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalyst in the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation is illustrated in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7a reveals that all the catalysts exhibit good stability throughout the 196 h time-on-stream. The catalytic activity rises in the initial stage, and an induction period is required to attain a steady state. It takes about 50 h for the Ce-0 to Ce-5 samples to reach a steady state, whereas the induction period of the Ce-20 catalyst is shortened to approximately 20 h. The reconstruction of the surface and bulk structures of the catalysts occurred during the induction period under high-temperature steam and ethylbenzene. The bulk phase transforms from potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17 to a mixture of metastable KFe11O17, KFeO2, and Fe3O4 phases, and a thin layer of active phase KFeO2 and a KOH/K2CO3 liquid film are formed on the surface [5,6]. Simultaneously, combined with the H2-TPR results, catalysts with better reducibility are found to be more amenable to active phase under the reaction conditions, exhibiting a shorter induction period. Therefore, it can be inferred that the length of the induction period is linked to the reducibility of the catalyst. The steady-state ethylbenzene conversions of Ce-0 and Ce-2.5 are approximately 66% and 74%, while the styrene selectivities are 92.5% and 91.7%, respectively. This means that the addition of a small amount of Ce can enhance the catalytic activity significantly. With the addition of Ce, ethylbenzene conversion increases gradually, but the selectivity of styrene tends to decrease. The highest ethylbenzene conversion is observed in Ce-20, reaching 77.8%, whereas the lowest styrene selectivity is observed, at 89.1%. Owing to the opposite trend of conversion and selectivity with Ce content, the yield of styrene displays a "volcanic curve" (Fig. 7b), reaching a maximum of 70.9% with Ce-12 catalyst. According to XRD grain size analysis, the growth in Ce content primarily increases the number of CeO2 nanoparticles [11]. One of the reaction steps of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation is a diproton extraction process realized by acid-base reaction and the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle. The reversible conversion of Ce4+/Ce3+ (standard electrode potential: 1.44 V) accelerates Fe2+/Fe3+ (Standard electrode potential: 0.77 V) redox cycle [40]; meanwhile, nano-CeO2 with oxygen vacancies can promote H2 desorption [41], both of which are beneficial to the catalytic activity. In addition, increasing Ce content reduces the selectivity of styrene and significantly increases the selectivity of toluene, from 3.9% of Ce-0 to 8.1% of Ce-20. Since toluene mainly arises from the hydrogenation of styrene [42], CeO2 with oxygen vacancies readily dissociates hydrogen to form Ce-H species under a high-temperature reducing atmosphere [43] and subsequently promotes the hydrogenation of adsorbed species of styrene intermediate to form toluene, thus diminishing the styrene selectivity with the rise in CeO2 content. The formation of byproduct benzene is generally attributed to the cracking of ethylbenzene on the acidic sites of the catalyst surface. The benzene selectivity decreases slightly with the addition of Ce, for which the decrease in the number and strength of Fe3+ acid sites on the surface of potassium polyferrite may account (Fig. 8 ). Potassium loss has long been a challenge faced by industrial styrene catalysts. Despite exhibiting no decline in activity or yield during the 196 h stability test, a pronounced phenomenon of K loss was observed in the spent catalysts. Firstly, based on the XRD spectra of Ce-0 and Ce-12 catalysts after reaction (Fig. S2), Fe3O4 was detected in Ce-0, while Fe3O4 and CeO2 were detected in Ce-12. However, the K-containing phase could not be detected in the bulk phase structure. This may be attributed to the loss of K, as well as the existing storage, ex-situ test conditions, and the metastable properties of KFeO2 [5,36]. Moreover, ICP-OES analysis (Fig. 9 ) of the catalyst particles after reaction revealed that compared to the fresh catalysts, the bulk K content of Ce-0 and Ce-12 particles decreased from 9.96% and 8.76% to 8.68% and 8.51%, respectively, with K loss rates of 12.8% and 2.9% before and after the reaction, respectively. Additionally, EDS mapping results of the particle side pre- and post-reaction (Fig. 9 and Table S1) showed that the K content of Ce-0 and Ce-12 catalysts decreased from 10.39% and 8.97% before reaction to 0.48% and 2.18% after reaction, respectively. Compared with the EDS point scan spectra before the reaction (Fig. S1), Fig. 10 indicates that CeO2 is still concentrated on the surface of the potassium polyferrite. However, the Ka peak of K on the side surface of the spent particle is noticeably diminished after the reaction, which suggests significant K loss on the surface of the catalyst. In summary, the K loss rate of the Ce-containing catalyst was significantly lower than that of the Ce-free Fe-K-Mg catalyst, which is consistent with Kotarba et al.'s study [16,44]. The K content in the spent catalyst particles was not uniform, and surface K loss was more significant under superheated steam flushing. Notably, the grain size of the CeO2 corresponding to the diffraction peak of (111) plane in Ce-12 catalysts after reaction was 34.9 nm, significantly higher than the 20.2 nm in fresh Ce-12, manifesting CeO2 grains exhibited significant agglomeration after the stability test. It should be mentioned that the development of industrial catalysts should not only prioritize catalytic performance but also take into account their physical properties. As large-scale styrene plants continue to evolve, the requirements for catalysts with optimal physical properties becomes increasingly significant. Although a high styrene yield is achieved with CeO2 content greater than 12%, the crush strength of such catalyst is lower than 73.0 N/5 mm, which falls short of the requirements for sustained operation of large-scale units. As a result, potential catalysts for this system should be optimized between 5% and 12% CeO2 content in order to strike a balance between physical properties and catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions This paper investigates the impact of CeO2 on the physical and chemical properties of Fe-K-Mg catalysts and their performance in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. Studies demonstrate that the catalyst's bulk density and crush strength exhibit a negative correlation with pore size and pore volume, and a positive correlation with the grain size of potassium β-ferrite. The surface of the catalyst without Ce consists mainly of potassium polyferrite and potassium carbonate, while the bulk phase structure primarily comprises potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17. Addition of a small amount of Ce promotes the formation of hexagonal potassium polyferrite and has a negligible impact on reducing the Fe-K-Mg catalyst. When the CeO2 content exceeds 12%, the grain size of potassium β-ferrite declines significantly, and nano-sized iron oxide emerges. The catalyst containing 20% CeO2 exhibits the highest quantity of small-sized iron oxide, and the reducibility substantially improves. Combining performance with TPR results, the better the reducibility of the catalyst, the shorter the induction period of the dehydrogenation reaction. Ethylbenzene conversion rises with CeO2 content, but the styrene selectivity exhibits the opposite trend, and the yield of styrene follows a "volcanic curve" tendency. In this system, CeO2 adheres to the surface of potassium β-ferrite in the form of nanoparticles, and increasing CeO2 content mainly increases the number of nano-CeO2 grains. CeO2 introduction significantly improves catalytic activity, likely by promoting Fe2+/Fe3+ redox and H2 desorption. With increasing CeO2 content, the decrease in strength and number of acid sites leads to a slight drop in benzene selectivity. After the stability test, K loss on the surface of catalyst particles was more significant than on the whole, and Ce introduction slowed down the K loss rate of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The continuous pursuit of green, low-carbon, and efficient processes in catalysis necessitates a deep understanding of catalytic reaction mechanisms and the structure-performance relationship of catalysts. Styrene, a vital monomer in the chemical industry, is primarily produced through the catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene over Fe-based catalysts. This study prepared a series of Fe-K-Mg catalysts promoted with different CeO2 contents. Various techniques such as mercury intrusion, particle strength tests, scanning electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and temperature-programmed techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts' physical properties, surface, and bulk structures. The results indicate that the bulk density and crush strength of the catalyst are closely related to the pore structure and grain size of potassium β-ferrite. The surface of the Ce-promoted catalyst contains potassium β-ferrite KFe11O17, cerium dioxide, and potassium carbonate, while the bulk structure consists of potassium β-ferrite and cerium dioxide. The addition of Ce enhances the catalytic activity of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, but the selectivity of styrene shows the opposite trend. The Fe-K-Mg catalyst containing 12% CeO2 exhibited the highest single-pass yield of styrene, reaching 70.9%. This study also discusses the possible effect of CeO2 on the performance of the Fe-K-Mg catalyst for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Ce-promoted Fe-K-Mg catalyst and its application in dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene
